title: 110_s3370
content: The "Libyan Claims Resolution Act" defines key terms such as "appropriate congressional committees," "claims agreement," "national of the United States," and "Secretary." The "Libyan Claims Resolution Act" defines key terms like "Secretary" as the Secretary of State and "state sponsor of terrorism" as a country supporting international terrorism. Congress supports the President in compensating US nationals with terrorism-related claims against Libya through an international agreement. The Libyan Claims Resolution Act establishes an agreement between the United States and Libya to compensate US nationals with terrorism-related claims. The Secretary may designate entities to assist in providing compensation, with immunity from judicial review. The Libyan Claims Resolution Act allows the Secretary to designate entities for compensating US nationals with terrorism-related claims, granting them immunity from judicial processes for related properties. Entities designated by the Secretary can hold, transfer, or receive properties under the Libyan Claims Resolution Act. Entities designated by the Secretary under the Libyan Claims Resolution Act are not liable for actions taken to implement claims agreements and are not subject to the Government Corporation Control Act. Libya and its entities are granted immunity from exceptions to immunity upon certification. Libya and its entities are granted immunity from exceptions to immunity from jurisdiction, liens, attachment, and execution under certain sections of the United States Code. Libya and its entities are granted immunity from jurisdiction, liens, attachment, and execution in Federal or State courts. Any judicial process against Libyan property or officials related to actions covered by the immunity is void. Certification by the Secretary to Congress is required to ensure funds for settlements. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2008 grants fair compensation to US nationals for wrongful death or injury claims against Libya. This includes cases pending on the date of enactment under specific sections of the United States Code. The Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 (Public Law 110-181) applies to conduct before June 30, 2006. The Secretary's certification in subsection (a)(2) cannot be delegated or reviewed judicially.
